intro: Galium decipiens var. hispidum, commonly known as the hairy bedstraw, is a flowering plant native to parts of Europe and Asia. It belongs to the Rubiaceae family and is characterized by its slender, branched stems covered in fine, stiff hairs. The plant produces small, white or pale yellow flowers that bloom in clusters, typically from late spring to early summer. Its leaves are opposite, ovate, and often have a slightly hairy texture. It thrives in moist, shaded environments such as woodlands and stream banks.
